lines.text: Do you remember anything about what happened?
Well, I remember leaving my office Friday afternoon. I was driving up to the country to have dinner with a client. After that, I'm a total blank until I woke up in ICU.
So, you're missing a whole week.
If you come across it, I'd like to have it back again.
Did they tell you the first person on the scene was a guy who was a medic in Vietnam?

Yeah. I was lying there on the pavement. My neck was broken; I wasn't breathing and this guy came along and he literally took a Swiss army knife and dug a hole in my throat and stuck a straw in it and saved my life.
Lucky he happened by.
Sometimes I wish he'd been running five minutes late that night.
[uncomfortable pause]
Was it my fault?
We're not sure yet.
It's been three weeks.

It's been four. You're missing one, remember? We have no witnesses to the actual crash; the other driver's blood alcohol level was slightly elevated and judging from impact, you were both doing the obligatory ten miles an hour over the speed limit.
What's the other driver have to say?
They didn't tell you? She died at the scene.
What you doing here sitting in the dark?
Spying on my neighbors. I think she's just discovered that her husband's go an online girlfriend. Now she's really reading him the riot act.
Serious melodrama.
I'm telling you.
I'm gonna have to try and fix you up one of those personal surveillance devices. Get you that all-important bird's-eye view.
Would that make me a bona fide, no-two-ways-about-it peeping tom?
Definitely.
Go for it!

[looking through the camera at the Thorpes' apartment]
She didn't leave him.
How can you be so sure?
Well, her jewelry box and her perfume are still on the dresser. She might leave her husband, but she's not gonna leave her jewelry.
That's my point, something must have happened to her.

Jason, she probably spent the day at a bar or at her sister's or her mother's trying to get up the courage to come home. She's gonna come home, she'll be remorseful, they'll be all lovey-dovey for a few days and then they'll go at it again. Relationships like that are far too complicated to understand from the outside. Next time, do us all a favor and don't call 911.
I'm not sure there's gonna be a next time. I think he killed her last night.
Run that by me again.

So, he makes bail, he comes home and he tell her he's gonna leave her for another woman. She threatens to testify against him and ruin his life. They have a drag-out fight and this time, he kills her.
So what do you think?
Aside from no body, no witnesses, no evidence whatsoever that a crime was committed... as crackpot theories go, very plausible.
Are you cynical, Charlie, or just apathetic?
Did you see this murder?
I heard it.
You heard them fighting, which married couples do from time to time.
I heard her scream and then I heard him banging and sawing away all night in his studio.
Residential zoning violation and not very neighborly, but hardly a capital crime.
He was covering up a murder!
Look, I hate to be cynical, but you're lying in bed, you can't sleep, you're looking at the ceiling, you start to imagine things.
I didn't imagine this.
Alison, did you hear a scream?
Well, I was downstairs.
Alison, are you telling me you didn't hear Mrs. Thorpe scream?
No, I didn't. I'm sorry. I might have been in the laundry room. I have a monitor in there so I can hear Jason, but I can't really hear anything from outside.
All right, no corroboration on the blood-curdling scream. Yet... I'll canvas the neighbors.

[flatly]
Great.

[looking at the camera]
Too bad that wasn't going last night. We could have gone to the videotape.
[to Jason]
You mind me asking, what kind of medication are you on?
You name it...
Alison, help me out here. He on anything which would affect his judgment or perception?
Sleeping pills and valium.

[dictating to his email]
"I know that woman's not your wife. I know what you did. I know who you are. And you won't get away with it." Send.
[to Claudia]
Now we wait.

[email]
What do you want?
What do I want? What *do* I want?
[to computer]
"I want to nail you, pal. I want to make you pay for what you've done. I want you to lie awake and wonder when they're coming to get you." Send.
[Jason watches through the window as Thorpe and his girlfriend read the email and start to panic]
you're gonna die. If you give me the proper password, no one else will get hurt. If you don't, I'm gonna kill her
[points at Alison]
I'm gonna burn this place to the ground and YOU'RE GONNA WATCH!
